ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Oxygen pressure induced structure, morphology and phase-transition for VO2/c-sapphire films by PLD

Affiliation.OrgName: University of Science and Technology of China

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: To investigate the effects of oxygen pressure on the structural and phase transition properties for VO2/c-sapphire, highly orientated VO2 thin films were grown on (0001) sapphire substrates by pulsed laser deposition (PLD) with different oxygen pressures. The crystal structure, morphology and component of the films were systematically investigated. The temperature-dependent resistance (R-T) measurement was conducted, which showed the distinct phase transition characteristic for the prepared films. The results indicate that the oxygen pressure plays an important role for the VO2 film preparation. The film grown at 1.7 Pa has lower phase transition temperature, higher film strain, and smaller grain size than that at 5.4 Pa, while no obvious crystal phase transition is observed. The experiment suggests that even a small change in oxygen pressure can influence the structure, morphology and phase-transition behavior of VO2 films obviously, and its potential causes are mainly attributed to the reduction of the kinetic energy to the substrate for target atoms caused by the oxygen pressure, the resulting grain aggregation and interfacial stress.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
It is well known that vanadium dioxide (VO2) undergoes a first phase transition at a critical temperature (T
c ), resulting in abrupt changes in its optical, electrical, and magnetic properties [1]. Due to these distinct properties, VO2 material shows high potential for various applications, such as electronic switches, thermal sensors, optical data storage disks, and thermochromic smart windows [2–5]. For the practical application of VO2, many methods such as doping transition metal ions [6, 7], engineering film stress [8, 9] and changing crystalline size [10] were adopted to adjust the critical temperature T
c for various applications. Vanadium oxide, which consists of various components of vanadium and oxygen, can be identified by its lattice structure and spacing group. Due to the narrow component range of each vanadium oxide and various crystal structure of VO2, it is very difficult to prepare single phase and highly orientated VO2 film with good stoichiometry.

Up to now, various techniques have been employed to prepare VO2 thin films such as pulse laser deposition (PLD) [11], sol-gel process [12], metal organic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) [13], magnetron sputtering [14], and evaporation. Among them, the PLD method is one of the most advanced techniques as the growth process can be precisely controlled. Compared with other techniques, the PLD technique is more convenient for preparing the metal oxide thin films with high quality, since the atoms or clusters fabricated by the pulsed laser ablation are very energetic and the mobility can be easily controlled by changing the deposition parameters.

VO2 film is usually grown on single crystalline substrates with suitable lattice constants such as sapphire or TiO2 substrates. It has been reported that the resistivity change of a high quality VO2 film can achieve 3∼4 orders of magnitude across the transition temperature. During the fabrication of VO2 thin films by PLD, the oxygen pressure is suggested to be an important factor. Because of its half-filled d-shell, vanadium possesses a set of valence states and prefers to form a number of oxides such as VO, V2O3, VO2, and V2O5. Thus, the forming condition of VO2 films prepared from a V2O5 target by laser ablation is very sensitive to the oxygen pressure. Fan et al. [11] deposited high quality VO2 film on a sapphire substrate using a VO2 target with the PLD method and found that the oxygen pressure at 3.6 Pa corresponded to B-VO2 while oxygen pressure lower than 1.8 Pa tended to M-VO2. Wu et al. [15] pulse laser deposited epitaxial VO2 thin films on (0001) sapphire with a vanadium target. During their deposition, the oxygen pressure and growth temperature were set at 6.6 Pa and 500 ∘C, respectively. Although a lot of experiments with the VO2 films preparation by the PLD method with VO2 or metallic V targets have been reported [16–20], the VO2 deposition directly from the cheaper V2O5 target is seldom investigated [21]. For further study of the detailed effects of oxygen pressure on the properties of VO2 thin films and their potential mechanism, the oxygen pressure induced differences on structure, component, morphology, and temperature-dependent resistance properties of VO2 film should be systematically investigated.

In this work, we have prepared high quality VO2 films with a V2O5 target on a c-sapphire crystal substrate with different oxygen pressures. It is observed that the structures and phase-transition properties of the obtained VO2 films seriously depend on the oxygen pressure during the deposition process. Even a small oxygen pressure change will induce a distinct variation for the prepared VO2 thin films, without causing any crystal phase transition.

Section2.Heading: Fabrication of VO2 films
Section2.Para: The VO2 films were deposited on c-plane sapphire substrates by the PLD technique (KrF pulse laser, 248 nm wavelength with a 5 Hz pulse frequency) with a V2O5 ceramic target (99.9 %). The laser pulse has the power of 200 mJ/cm2, and the base pressure was better than 4×10−4 Pa. The substrate, which was carefully cleaned by acetone, ethanol, and distilled water in an ultrasonic cleaner for 5 min each and then blown dry using a nitrogen flux, was placed in front of the target with the distance of 4 cm. The substrate temperature was set at 530 ∘C. During the deposition, both the target and the substrate rotated along the vertical axis to improve the uniformity of VO2 films. The oxygen flux pressure was kept at 1.7 Pa or 5.4 Pa by a mass flow controller. After deposition, the films were cooled down naturally to room temperature.

Section2.Heading: Sample characterization
Section2.Para:
X-ray diffraction (XRD, Cu Kα, PHILIPS X’Pert PRO) measurements in θ–2θ mode were carried out to examine the crystal structures of the as-prepared VO2 films. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed in a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB250Xi system, equipped with a hemispherical energy analyzer, with a base pressure of 3×10−8 Pa. The surface morphologies and the grain structures of the films were investigated by a field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, JEOL JSM-6700F) with an acceleration voltage of 5.0 kV. The temperature dependent resistance was measured using a homemade resistance measurement system. T
c value of VO2 thin film has been obtained by calculating the middle point of the total integrated area of the hysteresis loop.

Section2.Heading: Results of XRD measurements
Section2.Para:
Figure 1 shows the θ–2θ XRD patterns of the VO2 thin films deposited on c-sapphire at oxygen pressure of 1.7 Pa and 5.4 Pa, respectively. Besides the Al2O3(0006) substrate peak, both films have only one diffraction peak located around 39.9, which comes from the diffractions at (002) or (020) planes of the VO2 (M) phase. Many research groups reported results assuming this peak to be (020) plane [15, 22–25] showing preferred oriented growth. However, a recent report has clarified that the orientation of heteroepitaxially grown VO2 film on c-sapphire is (002) [16, 26–28]. Considering the similar experimental details with Koo’s report [29], here we prefer to assign the orientation of this plane to be (002).
Fig. 1
XRD patterns of VO2 films grown on Al2O3(0001) substrates at oxygen pressure of 5.4 Pa and 1.7 Pa, respectively

Both the diffraction peak position and the full width at half-maximum (FWHM) are obtained by Gauss fitting, and the grain sizes are calculated by using Scherrer’s equation. The detailed results are listed in Table 1. From which, it can be found that both two samples have a very close grain size, e.g., 44 nm for film at 5.4 Pa and 42 nm for film at 1.7 Pa. The FWHM of the (002) peak is small (∼0.2∘), which indicates the high crystalline quality of the films. It is noticed that the positions of diffraction peak for both films are different; the film at 5.4 Pa is located at 39.94∘ while that at 1.7 Pa located at 40.14∘, suggesting the later have smaller interplanar distance than the former. According to the JCDPDS data (#82-0661) for VO2, the (002) lattice spacing of VO2 is 0.22672 nm and the standard position is 39.724∘. The d (002) of VO2 at 5.4 Pa is 0.22553 nm, which is smaller than 0.22672 nm, indicating that the film is under slight strain along the film plane. The compression of the c-space of film at 5.4 Pa is obtained to be 0.52 %. By the same rule, it can estimate that the film at 1.7 Pa shows the compression of 1.04 % as well. It is suggested that the less oxygen pressure involved, the bigger film strain induced. According to the results reported by Muraoka et al. [30], such large c-space compress will result in the variation of phase-transition temperature of VO2 thin films, which will be discussed in detail later.
Table 1

Section2.Heading: XPS measurements
Section2.Para:
XPS was performed to understand the detailed components of the films. A wide range survey spectra (not displayed here) suggested the presence of oxygen, vanadium, carbon, and nitrogen. The vanadium and part of oxygen signals came from the VO2 film, and part of oxygen and nitrogen were a contaminant and could be removed by Ar+ etching. Figure 2(a) and (b) show the high resolved XPS results for the films prepared at 5.4 Pa and 1.7 Pa. Two main peaks located at around 516 eV and 523 eV were attributed to V2p3/2 and V2p1/2, respectively. To determine the different vanadium oxidation states in VO2 film, we adopted Silversmit’s method [31]. The O1s core level, as an internal binding energy reference, was centered at 530.0 eV. The binding energy (BE) span between O1s and V2p3/2 core level was utilized as a criterion to judge the different vanadium oxidation states. The BE spans are gained as 13.9 eV for both samples, in well agreement with Blauw’s report [32]. This result suggests that the main component of our films is VO2. From Fig. 2(a) and (b), we also observed that the V2p3/2 peaks are asymmetric, a trace amount of V5+ (derived from surface oxidization either in the annealing process or during storage in air) [33, 34] was confirmed to exist only on the surfaces (the top several nanometers) by Ar+ etching. In order to investigate the valence state variety of vanadium in the sample, we analyzed the V2p3/2 peak by Xpeak 4.1 software [35] in detail and a Shirley function was used to subtract the background (shown in Fig. 2(c) and (d)). Similar to the previous report [36], we attributed the peaks of 517.3 eV and 516.1 eV to V5+ and V4+, respectively. The fitting results showed the main component for both films are V4+, and the content of V5+ are 29 at.% and 24 at.% for films grown at 5.4 Pa and 1.7 Pa. Comparatively, the former is slightly more than the later, which is probably relative with surface roughness. The rougher the surface is, the easier it oxidizes. This case will be confirmed by the subsequent SEM measurements.
Fig. 2
High-resolution XPS spectra of VO2 films on Al2O3 (0006) under oxygen pressure: (a) 5.4 Pa, and (b) 1.7 Pa. (c) and (d) are the fitting results for sample at 5.4 Pa and 1.7 Pa, respectively

Section2.Heading: Surface morphology
Section2.Para:
The microstructure of VO2 thin films and the cross-section was characterized by SEM shown in Fig. 3. The surface morphologies of both samples are quite flat. The related cross-section images show obvious edges, and both films have the same thickness of about 100 nm with smooth and compact structures. The grain size for film at 5.4 Pa is about 75 nm, much larger than the film at 1.7 Pa (36 nm). The later value is basically consistent with that from XRD, while the grain size for film at 5.4 Pa is much larger than that from XRD (44 nm). It indicated the grain for film at 5.4 Pa is composed of several crystallites. It is suggested that the introduction of more oxygen makes the grain size larger. This can be explained as the following: The higher oxygen pressure prevents the atoms in the deposition flux having enough kinetic energy to diffuse along the film surface, resulting in crystal grain reunion and the formation of large particles. The larger grain size means a less number of grain boundaries and will reduce the resistance of VO2 films. Considering the results from XRD, the formation of large grains for the film at 5.4 Pa probably further relaxes the strain between the film and substrate. In comparison, the film at 1.7 Pa shows the larger interface strain due to the lattice misfit, which reduces the value of d (002) and will also affect the transition temperature of film. This case will be discussed in the following R-T curve analysis. In addition, the rough film surface has a larger surface area, resulting in the formation of more V5+ components, which is well consistent with XPS analysis.
Fig. 3
Surface morphologies of VO2 thin film prepared at 5.4 Pa (a) and 1.7 Pa (c); the corresponding cross-sections for film at 5.4 Pa (b) and at 1.7 Pa (d), respectively

Section2.Heading: Temperature-dependent resistance measurement
Section2.Para:
The electrical properties of VO2 films have been investigated by a temperature-dependent resistance measurement shown in Fig. 4. Regardless of the high crystallinity of VO2 thin film as shown in XRD data (Fig. 1), the resistance of film at 1.7 Pa showed low resistance at room temperature compared with that at 5.4 Pa. Normally, the lower oxygen pressure should be linked with more oxygen deficiency, and these extra electrons would decrease the π ∗ bands level and reduce the gap, resulting in the drop of film resistance for film prepared at low oxygen pressure [37]. However, during the process of the above XPS fitting, no obvious V3+ component was found for both samples, suggesting the low resistance at room temperature for the sample at 1.7 Pa cannot be ascribed to oxygen deficiency. We also noticed another factor, d(002), which will influence the resistance of film at 1.7 Pa as well. From XRD results, the film at 1.7 Pa corresponds to smaller (002) interplanar distance, suggesting stronger stain and lower phase transition than that at 5.4 Pa. In addition, at high temperature (360 K), the film resistance at 1.7 Pa showed higher value than that at 5.4 Pa. As discussed from SEM results, it is suggested that lower oxygen pressure results in smaller grain size; the increase of atoms accounts at grain boundary will also result in a higher resistance value.
Fig. 4
Temperature dependence of resistance for the VO2 films grown at 5.4 Pa and 1.7 Pa, respectively

The T
c of thin film for each sample was determined by calculating the mid-point of an integrated hysteresis loop area. The film at 1.7 Pa had lower T
c of 338 K compared with 343 K of film at 5.4 Pa. Based on the XRD results, it can be explained in terms of Muraoka’s theory [30]. Generally, the stability of a metallic phase in VO2 depends on the c-axis length, i.e., the V4+–V4+ distance in the crystal structure. The reduced c-space will result in a drop of transition temperature. In our case, the film at 1.7 Pa has the compression of 1.04 % along the c-axis, which should be the reason for the drop of transition temperature. Comparing Muraoka’s results that the film with a 0.86 % c-axis stress corresponds to 300 K of transition temperature, the film at 1.7 Pa in our case should correspond to a lower transition temperature than 300 K. The noncoincidence is probably due to the film thickness of our film, about 100 nm, and is much larger than reported (10–15 nm) by Muraoka. With the increase of film thickness, the stress along the c-axis should be relaxed, resulting in the limited drop of T
c . According to the report from the F C Case group [9], VO2 thin films with 300 nm thickness, which were deposited on different substrates have different T
c values, suggesting that the tensile stress applied on the film by thermal stress can cause T
c change with a linear relationship between T
c and thermal stress. But in our experiment, the substrates are the same and the effect of thermal stress induced by the substrate for these two samples can be negligible. In Fan’s work [11], M-VO2 thin films were grown at oxygen pressure of 3.6 Pa, but in this paper, 5.4 Pa seems to correspond to a better growth condition. This indicates that, for the PLD deposition, the target will also affect the final VO2 film quality besides oxygen pressure, which needs further investigation.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para:
With the oxygen pressures of 1.7 Pa and 5.4 Pa, high oriented VO2 thin films were prepared on c-cut sapphire substrates by the PLD method directly from the cheap V2O5 ceramic target. The oxygen pressure induced different crystal structures, components, surface morphologies, and electric properties of films were systematically investigated. Both films showed (002) preferred orientation without other crystal structures occurring. The film grown at lower oxygen pressure showed the smaller c-space, smaller grain size, and lower transition temperature. The T
c were 343 K and 338 K for VO2/c-sapphire samples prepared at 5.4 Pa and 1.7 Pa, respectively. The results suggest that even a small change in oxygen pressure can influence the structure, morphology, and phase-transition behavior of VO2 films obviously, without causing any crystal phase transition.
